text:
ANDERSON COOPER:
OK, here's the deal.

We're breaking
format for this story
because I just had to do it.

If you know, I fly a
lot, and maybe you've

heard over the
years I'm obsessed

with people and their
naked feet on airplanes.

I've been on so many
flights where people have

been walking around
without their shoes
on or putting their shoes--
their feet very close.
I just find it so disgusting.

And I've got to introduce
you to this next person.

This poor person
was made to suffer
the stuff of my nightmares.
Her name is Jessie Char.

She thought she hit the
jackpot on a JetBlue flight

from Long Beach, California, to
her home in San Francisco when

she had two open seats next
to her, which is the dream
on any JetBlue flight.

You get the whole
row to yourself.
But to her horror--

and mine, frankly-- this
is what happened next.
Take a look at this photo.
Yeah, that's right.

This little piggy
went to market.
This little piggy stayed home.

And this little piggy
in the seat behind her

boarded a JetBlue
flight and decided

to just let it all
hang out, just let
those dogs out and let 'em fly.

Joining me now, the
poor, unfortunate

soul who endured this affront
to all humanity, Jessie Char.

Jessie, thank you
for being with us.

I have been on a
tear about naked feet
on flights for years.

So when I saw this, I felt your
pain, and I had to talk to you.
What happened?

When did you first
notice these feet?

JESSIE CHAR: So I
had intentionally
left the armrests on my plane--

or on my row up so
that I could enjoy
my expansive bench in the sky.

But shortly after
takeoff, I noticed

that one of the armrests
kind of fell down.

I thought it was just
a gravity situation.

But when I looked
over, I saw this kind

of serpentine set
of toes wiggling
out from the row behind me.
ANDERSON COOPER: Oh, gross.
JESSIE CHAR: Yeah.

ANDERSON COOPER: So it was one
foot first and then the other
or both feet at the same time?

JESSIE CHAR: Oh, it
was one foot first,
just to test the waters--

ANDERSON COOPER:
Sure, of course.

JESSIE CHAR: --and then the
next foot following after it.

ANDERSON COOPER:
That's how they do it.

JESSIE CHAR: Yeah, he had
to make sure it was safe.

ANDERSON COOPER:
I was on a plane

once where someone
had their feet--

they had the row at
the front of the plane,

so they had their
feet up on the front

so that everybody behind
them could see their feet.

I've even been on a
plane where someone
was clipping their toenails.

JESSIE CHAR: Oh,
that's so much worse.

ANDERSON COOPER: It's bad,
but this is so disturbing,

especially when
you think you have

the whole row to yourself,
which is the greatest
thrill of all on a plane.

JESSIE CHAR: It was quite
a disappointment, yes.

ANDERSON COOPER: Now did you
say anything to this person?
JESSIE CHAR: I didn't.

I wanted to get a
flight attendant,

because I wanted another human
to witness what was happening.

I was alone in my row, so
there was nobody around.

And I worried that
nobody would believe
me if I had just told her.

I waited for a flight
attendant to come.

But by the time somebody
finally came over to me,

the feet kind of descended
back from whence they came.
ANDERSON COOPER: Oh, OK.

So they retracted
their hobbit feet.

JESSIE CHAR: Yes, but not
until after opening and closing

the window shutter
with their feet.
ANDERSON COOPER: No!
Oh, come on!
That's-- really?
JESSIE CHAR: It's real.
It really happened.
ANDERSON COOPER: Oh my god.
All right.
JESSIE CHAR: I know.

ANDERSON COOPER: You can't make
that stuff-- that is insane.

Now also, then
there's the dilemma
of, do you want to touch the--

I don't want to sound like
a complete germaphobe,

but do you want to then
touch those armrests
after those feet--

JESSIE CHAR: No, I sure
didn't want to touch 'em!
I just left it down.
I was not-- yeah.

ANDERSON COOPER:
So at that point,

you just gave up the
fantasy of having
the whole row to yourself?
JESSIE CHAR: Yes.
ANDERSON COOPER: Wow.

What are we going to
do about this, Jessie?

How are we going
to stop this trend?

JESSIE CHAR: Oh
god, I don't know
how are we going to stop it.

Thousands of people
have seen this

and have seen the shame
that has been brought
upon this mystery person.

But I don't know,
just keep your--
at least keep your socks on.

ANDERSON COOPER:
Socks on are fine!

Well, Jessie, I'm glad
you made it through,

and I'm glad you took the
photograph to document this.

And know next time
this happens, just--

I don't know-- call me, and
we'll figure out something.

JESSIE CHAR: Oh, I'll
call you, Anderson.
ANDERSON COOPER: All right.
Jessie Char, thanks so much.
JESSIE CHAR: All right.
Thank you.
